Generation I.Red: When it targets an enemy, it charges furiously while whipping its body with its long tails.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: When it targets an enemy, it charges furiously while whipping its body with its long tails.
Generation I.Yellow: A rowdy Pok é mon with a lot of stamina. Once running, it won't stop until it hits something.
Generation I.Stadium: Charges while whipping its hefty body with its tails. Although powerful, it can charge only in a straight line.

Generation II.Gold: They fight each other by locking horns. The herd's protector takes pride in its battle-scarred horns.
Generation II.Silver: After heightening its will to fight by whipping itself with its three tails, it charges at full speed.
Generation II.Crystal: These violent Pokémon fight with other members of their herd in order to prove their strength.
Generation II.Stadium 2: They fight each other by locking horns. The herd's protector takes pride in its battle-scarred horns. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) After heightening its will to fight by whipping itself with its three tails, it charges at full speed. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: This Pok é mon is not satisfied unless it is rampaging at all times. If there is no opponent for Tauros to battle, it will charge at thick trees and knock them down to calm itself.
Generation III.Sapphire: This Pok é mon is not satisfied unless it is rampaging at all times. If there is no opponent for Tauros to battle, it will charge at thick trees and knock them down to calm itself.
Generation III.Emerald: It is not satisfied unless it is rampaging at all times. If there is no opponent for Tauros to battle, it will charge at thick trees and knock them down to calm itself.
Generation III.FireRed: When it is about to Tackle , it whips its body repeatedly with its three long tails.
Generation III.LeafGreen: When it targets an enemy, it charges furiously while whipping its body with its long tails.

Generation IV.Diamond: Once it takes aim at its foe, it makes a headlong charge. It is famous for its violent nature.

Generation VI.X: After heightening its will to fight by whipping itself with its three tails, it charges at full speed.
Generation VI.Y: When it is about to tackle, it whips its body repeatedly with its three long tails.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: This Pokémon is not satisfied unless it is rampaging at all times. If there is no opponent for Tauros to battle, it will charge at thick trees and knock them down to calm itself.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: This Pokémon is not satisfied unless it is rampaging at all times. If there is no opponent for Tauros to battle, it will charge at thick trees and knock them down to calm itself.

Generation VII.Sun: Historically, people in areas all over the world have ridden Tauros, but the practice is said to have started in Alola.
Generation VII.Moon: Although it's known to be a fierce Pokémon, Tauros in the Alola region are said to possess a measure of calmness.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: They live in groups. The one with the longest, thickest, and most-scarred horns is the boss of the herd.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: The climate seems to be related to the reason Tauros in Alola are a little calmer than those in other regions.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: A rowdy Pokémon with a lot of stamina. Once running, it won't stop until it hits something.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: A rowdy Pokémon with a lot of stamina. Once running, it won't stop until it hits something.

Generation VIII.Sword: When Tauros begins whipping itself with its tails, it's a warning that the Pokémon is about to charge with astounding speed.
Generation VIII.Shield: The Tauros of Galar are volatile in nature, and they won't allow people to ride on their backs.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Once it takes aim at its prey, it makes a headlong charge. It is famous for its violent nature.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: Once it takes aim at its prey, it makes a headlong charge. It is famous for its violent nature.

Generation IX.Scarlet: This Pokémon blasts water from holes on the tips of its horns—the high-pressure jets pierce right through Tauros’s enemies.
Generation IX.Violet: It swims by jetting water from its horns. The most notable characteristic of the Aqua Breed is its high body fat, which allows it to float easily.
